@Jamie_Woodward_ @Malvernmeet @RobGMacfarlane @EnvAgency It's not even acceptable any more during high flows. At least as much plastic waste is discharged then.

@Jamie_Woodward_ @RobGMacfarlane @EnvAgency One problem is that the cheap sewer design allows rainwater, surface water and groundwater to get into the pipes. That gets worse over time and they are overloaded by water that shouldn't be there. It has to possible to build sealed sewers that don't allow extra water in. 2/2

RT @Feargal_Sharkey: They drain our chalk streams dry, dump over 3.1 million hours worth of sewage into our rivers and now this.

The water…

@Jamie_Woodward_ @RobGMacfarlane @EnvAgency I accept that. I too think that it's ludicrous that these untreated overflows are allowed at all.

The basic problem is the cheap way we have always built sewerage systems. The old combined systems are a well-known problem but overflows occur on supposed separate systems too. 1/2

urls.title: BRE Group: The SMARTeST FP7 Project and The Six Steps to Flood Resilience
urls.description: Recent flood events in Europe, and worldwide, demonstrate that existing flood defence structures do not guarantee a sufficient protection level for people and properties. New strategies aim for a more holistic approach to flood risk management; and to consider the uncertainties of a changing climate and increased urbanisation. The most important aspect of such strategies is their adaptability and flexibility. The market has seen the emergence of the flood resilience (FRe) technology in recent years which
